thread.title: Five things we learned about Penn State: Ohio State edition
thread.title_full: Five things we learned about Penn State: Ohio State edition

author: Mark Wogenrich
title: Five things we learned about Penn State: Ohio State edition
text:
Five things we learned about Penn State: Ohio State edition Penn State's Saquon Barkley returns against Ohio State 
Penn State coach James Franklin discusses Saquon Barkley's 194-yard game against Ohio State. 
Penn State coach James Franklin discusses Saquon Barkley's 194-yard game against Ohio State. Mark Wogenrich Contact Reporter Of The Morning Call Five things we learned from Penn State's 38-10 loss at Ohio State. 
Penn State thought its 38-10 loss to Ohio State was closer than the score indicated. Perhaps, especially considering the Lions had a shot at a 10-0 lead early. 
What else did we learn from the game? Here's a look. 
1. Saquon Barkley is the offense. 
Penn State rushed for 195 yards against the Buckeyes: Barkley, the freshman from Whitehall, had 194 of them. That didn't include a 44-yard touchdown run that was called back because of offensive line holding. 
Lineman Andrew Nelson described Barkley best. 
"He’s a make-it-right guy," the tackle said. "You may not get everything blocked exactly correctly, but he can make you right and make people miss. Definitely an explosive player." 
2. But what else is the offense? 
Aside from Barkley and two individual-effort plays from receivers Chris Godwin and DaeSean Hamilton, the Lions managed little against Ohio State. 
Godwin is Penn State's sole threat in one-on-one coverage, which he proved on a juggling catch that he extended to 56 yards with a second-effort run. Penn State's lone touchdown was all Hamilton. 
"We can build off the fact that we're starting to build an identity in the run game," Nelson said. 
See No. 1 for that identity. 
3. Penn State can't contain J.T. Barrett. 
This became evident last year, when the quarterback ran for two touchdowns in overtime and threw one in regulation. Penn State v Ohio State Jamie Sabau / Getty Images 
Ohio state quarterback J.T. Barrett ran for two touchdowns against Penn State. 
Ohio state quarterback J.T. Barrett ran for two touchdowns against Penn State. (Jamie Sabau / Getty Images) 
He added four more Saturday (two rushing, two throwing) and changed the way Penn State played defense. 
Even Penn State coach James Franklin wondered why Ohio State stuck with Cardale Jones early. 
"I thought we were playing pretty good when they had the traditional dropback quarterback," Franklin said. "... Now Barrett comes in. ... The combination of [Ezekiel Elliott], the quarterback and Braxton Miller, those guys just played at a different speed. That definitely factored in, no doubt about it." 
4. Franklin's tired of his punting. 
The coach brought this up himself, calling it a two-year trial. Punters Chris Gulla (who returned from injury) and Daniel Pasquariello averaged 35.9 yards per attempt, put one punt inside the 20-yard line (to Ohio State's four) and did not help Penn State flip field position. 
Penn State's 2016 recruiting class includes a scholarship punter: Blake Gillikin of Georgia. Until he arrives, Franklin might get creative. 
"If we need to have open tryouts, we’re going to have to find a way to solve that problem," the coach said said. 
5. Franklin will 'play to win' 
Hackenberg clearly was hurting in the second half, when he attempted four passes and was sacked three times. Penn State v Ohio State Jamie Sabau / Getty Images 
Penn State quarterback Christian Hackenberg completed a career-low seven passes against Ohio State. 
Penn State quarterback Christian Hackenberg completed a career-low seven passes against Ohio State. (Jamie Sabau / Getty Images) 
Yet he remained in the game down 28 points, as did Barkley and Akeel Lynch, who also returned from an injury this week. 
Both running backs took big hits in the fourth quarter, which certainly could have happened earlier in the game. With 4 minutes left, though, maybe it's time to lessen their risk. 
"We're going to play, no different than [Ohio State]," Franklin said. "Late in they game, they had [defensive end Joey] Bosa and their starting defense in there. We're still playing football to win."
